verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the LORD says: Let My people go, so that they may serve Me.’”
verses.comment: The phrase “Let My people go, so that they may serve Me” is repeated throughout the Exodus account, showing God’s desire for worship and service. This foreshadows the Christian calling to service and worship (Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: But if you refuse to let them go, behold, I will plague your whole territory with frogs.
verses.comment: God’s warnings escalate in severity, demonstrating both His justice and mercy in giving Pharaoh a clear choice. The plagues often symbolize the unraveling of creation, reflecting what happens when humanity rejects God’s order.

verses.text: The river will swarm with frogs; they will come up and enter your house, your bedroom, and onto your bed; into the houses of your servants and your people; into your ovens and your kneading bowls.
verses.comment: The infestation invades every aspect of Egyptian life, underscoring God’s absolute power. Such images point later to the fullness of redemption permeating every part of life (cf. 1 Cor. 6:20).

verses.text: The frogs will come up upon you and your people and all your servants.’”
verses.comment: Emphasizes the comprehensive nature of the plague. In biblical symbolism, frogs are sometimes linked to impurity (Rev. 16:13).

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Stretch out your hand with your staff over the rivers, canals, and ponds, and cause frogs to come up over the land of Egypt.’”
verses.comment: Aaron acts at Moses’ command, highlighting the order and authority in God’s covenant people. Staffs are symbols of leadership and spiritual authority—see Num. 17:8.

verses.text: Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: This act demonstrates the mediatory role of Aaron, anticipating later priestly mediation on behalf of God’s people. Mediators remain a theme throughout scripture (Heb. 5:1).

verses.text: But the magicians did the same with their secret arts and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: The magicians’ imitation highlights the limits of false power. Ultimately, God alone triumphs, which foreshadows Christ’s defeat of evil powers (Col. 2:15).

verses.text: Then Pharaoh called Moses and Aaron and said, “Pray to the LORD to take the frogs away from me and my people, and I will let the people go to sacrifice to the LORD.”
verses.comment: Pharaoh, despite his defiance, recognizes the distinctiveness of the LORD’s power and seeks intercession, prefiguring the value of intercessory prayer.

verses.text: Moses said to Pharaoh, “Set the time for me to pray for you, for your servants, and for your people, that the frogs may be removed from you and your houses and remain only in the Nile.”
verses.comment: This emphasizes the prophetic role of Moses as one through whom God hears and acts—anticipating Christ as the ultimate intercessor (Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: Pharaoh said, “Tomorrow.” Moses replied, “Let it be according to your word, that you may know there is no one like the LORD our God.”
verses.comment: Affirms God’s uniqueness and supremacy, a truth foundational to biblical revelation (Deut. 4:35; Isaiah 45:5).

verses.text: The frogs will leave you, your houses, your servants, and your people; they will remain only in the Nile.”
verses.comment: God’s control over the plague’s removal further demonstrates His sovereignty over creation and history.

verses.text: Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the LORD concerning the frogs He had brought upon Pharaoh.
verses.comment: This shows the humility of true spiritual leaders, trusting in God’s power, and echoes the need for fervent prayer.

verses.text: The LORD did as Moses asked, and the frogs died out from the houses, the courtyards, and the fields.
verses.comment: God’s hearing of Moses’ petition highlights the unique friendship and mediation between Moses and God.

verses.text: They piled the dead frogs in heaps, and the land stank.
verses.comment: The aftermath of judgement left a mark on the land, signifying that sin has lasting consequences even after its immediate removal.

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he hardened his heart and did not listen to them, just as the LORD had said.
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s hardened heart is a recurring theme (cf. Rom. 9:17-18). Persistent resistance to grace has serious spiritual consequences.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Stretch out your staff and strike the dust of the earth, so that it may become gnats throughout all the land of Egypt.’”
verses.comment: Gnats (or lice) from dust echo the curse of the ground after the Fall (Gen. 3:17). The staff again signifies divinely sanctioned authority.

verses.text: And they did so; Aaron stretched out his hand with his staff and struck the dust of the earth, and gnats came upon man and beast. All the dust of the earth became gnats throughout all Egypt.
verses.comment: The entire nation is afflicted, emphasizing divine judgement and the universal scope of sin and its effects.

verses.text: The magicians tried by their secret arts to produce gnats, but they could not. So there were gnats on man and beast.
verses.comment: Here, human power fails utterly before God. Such boundaries foreshadow the weakness of human efforts without divine grace.

verses.text: The magicians said to Pharaoh, “This is the finger of God.” But Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he would not listen to them, just as the LORD had said.
verses.comment: Recognition of ‘the finger of God’ is later echoed by Jesus casting out demons (Luke 11:20), showing continuity in God’s mighty acts.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Rise early in the morning and present yourself before Pharaoh as he comes out to the water and say to him, ‘This is what the LORD says: Let My people go, so that they may serve Me.’”
verses.comment: The repeated demand for worship establishes true religion as founded on obedience to God, not human rulers.

verses.text: If you do not let My people go, I will send swarms of flies upon you, your servants, your people, and into your houses. The houses of the Egyptians will be full of flies, and also the ground they stand on.
verses.comment: ‘Swarms of flies’ represent disorder and corruption. Purity and cleanliness are vital spiritual lessons (Matt. 23:27).

verses.text: But on that day, I will set apart the land of Goshen, where My people live, so that no swarms of flies will be there, so that you may know I am the LORD in the midst of the land.
verses.comment: God’s protection of Goshen prefigures spiritual preservation and distinction of the faithful. God’s presence among His people is central throughout scripture.

verses.text: I will put a division between My people and your people. Tomorrow this sign will occur.”
verses.comment: God’s act of separating His people points to election—God chooses and sets apart for His purpose, a theme carried forward into the New Covenant (Eph. 1:4).

verses.text: And the LORD did so; there came great swarms of flies into Pharaoh’s house and his servants’ houses; all the land of Egypt was ruined because of the swarms of flies.
verses.comment: Egypt’s devastation is a sign of divine judgement, similar to later events in Old Testament prophecy (Isaiah 10:22).

verses.text: Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “Go, sacrifice to your God in the land.”
verses.comment: Pharaoh proposes compromise, but true worship requires the place and manner ordained by God. Shows the necessity of worship in spirit and truth (John 4:24).

verses.text: But Moses said, “It would not be right to do so, for our sacrifices to the LORD our God would be an abomination to the Egyptians. If we sacrifice what is abominable to the Egyptians before their eyes, will they not stone us?”
verses.comment: Worship must be according to God’s prescription, even when that differs from surrounding cultures. The unity of worship in God’s people is an enduring theme.

verses.text: We must go three days’ journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the LORD our God, as He commands us.”
verses.comment: Emphasizes obedience to divine command rather than human negotiation. True worship always seeks God’s will above compromise.

verses.text: Pharaoh said, “I will let you go to sacrifice to the LORD your God in the wilderness, only do not go very far; plead for me.”
verses.comment: Pharaoh continues to seek limits; however, God calls for fullness of commitment—akin to whole-hearted discipleship (Luke 9:62).

verses.text: Moses said, “As soon as I leave you, I will pray to the LORD that the swarms of flies may depart from Pharaoh, his servants, and his people tomorrow. But let Pharaoh not deal falsely again by refusing to let the people go to sacrifice to the LORD.”
verses.comment: Warns of faithfulness. Moses models integrity and clear warning about disobedience, a trait necessary for spiritual leaders.

verses.text: So Moses went out from Pharaoh and prayed to the LORD.
verses.comment: Prayer as the means by which leaders seek God’s strength and favor is a recurring biblical principle.

verses.text: And the LORD did what Moses asked: He removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, his servants, and his people; not a single one remained.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the efficacy of intercessory prayer when offered with faith. God’s complete removal points to His total authority.

verses.text: But Pharaoh hardened his heart this time also and did not let the people go.
verses.comment: Again, persistent resistance to God signals spiritual danger. The need for conversion is underscored—foreshadowing the transformation that Christ brings (Acts 3:19).
